Expectation1: Respond to emails and messages within a reasonable time frame
Situation1: Leadership needs a prompt reply to confirm details for an external partner.
Expectation2: Follow traffic laws and drive defensively
Situation2: A school zone with children near the curb appears just as a construction detour narrows the lanes
Story: My phone buzzes insistently on the passenger seat, the screen lighting up with a message from my manager: “Need your confirmation ASAP—external partner waiting.” As a colleague, I know how important it is to respond quickly, especially when leadership is involved. I can almost feel the weight of their expectations pressing on my shoulders. But right now, I’m behind the wheel of my taxi, inching through a school zone. Children cluster near the curb, their laughter and sudden movements unpredictable. The construction detour has squeezed traffic into a single, narrow lane, and every driver seems impatient. I grip the steering wheel tighter, my eyes darting between the road and the glowing phone. I know I can’t risk a distracted moment here—one wrong move could endanger a child. Yet, the pressure to reply to my manager grows with every passing second. My mind races, torn between the urgent demands of my job as a colleague and my responsibility as a careful taxi driver. The tension knots in my chest, and I wrestle with what to do next.
